messages.content:
Greetings,

My goal is to convert an SHA3 hash (e.g. SHA3-512) into Field[], and then Poseidon.hash() that Field[]. My main question is how to convert SHA3 into Field[], or perhaps there is some other approach.

I just started investigating this, but perhaps someone has already worked on this. Want to make sure I make the convention correctly and don't end up decreasing the security guarantees.

For now my thoughts are to split the hash into chunks that fit into a Field, and hashing each chunk iteratively. My concern here is correctly fitting into a Field, as it's 254 bits, and not 256. 

Thanks.
After delving into the source of O1JS, I found out that the Field is 255 bits, not 254.

Oooor, would CircuitString converted .toFields() work? Passing the hex/string representation of SHA3-512 into a circuit and calling .toFields(). However, the docs mention that CircuitString is deprecated. 🤔 

Also, I'll need to verify how .toFields() is done to ensure that full-bit security of SHA3-512 is preserved.

Another option is a Struct with 3 fields. Splitting the SHA3-512 into 3 128bit Fields. This will make it fully verifiable. 

This is the version that I'm currently drafting.

I think splitting SHA3-512 hash into Field chunks by creating a struct is a good way.
It'll be the same data except it'll be in a different format that you can easily work with on Mina.

I'm converting SHA3-512 to 3 Fields and packing those 3 Fields together with other file metadata like size, mime type, and name to a small Merkle Tree:
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/src/storage/file.ts#L55
If you're solving the problem of putting file information to on-chain and off-chain storage, you can use classes File, FileData, IPFS, and ARWEAVE from the minanft library:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/minanft

Thanks for the answers!

Here is the solution that I drafted: https://github.com/iluxonchik/zkLocus/blob/main/contracts/src/model/public/SHA3.ts

You can find the tests in: https://github.com/iluxonchik/zkLocus/blob/main/contracts/src/tests/SHA3Slice.test.ts

(The files and code will probably move around. If you’re looking at this and it doesn’t make sense, let me know and I’ll give you an updated link)

messages.content: another option (you can check whats more efficient for your use case): `let fieldElements = digest.bytes.map(b => b.value)`

You can also take a look at the Keccak implementation to see how we can convert between bytes and compose them into other structures
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/keccak.ts#L515-L542

messages.content: Thanks @Florian ! True, keccak support wsa implement in 0.15. I'm developing another approach now, I will post back with updates

waaaait @Florian, can't I just do:

```
hash: Bytes = Keccak.nistSha3(512, Byes.fromString("Hello, ZK"));
hashAsUnit: Uint8[] = ? (convert somehow)
fields: Field[] = Keccak.bytesToWords(hashAsUint);
```
I skimmed through the code that you sent and it feels like it should work.

Are there any docs or examples? Thanks again.
Found these tests: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/015b0bfcdd9e8c5a25c6755182b7ab3a5132d6db/src/lib/keccak.unit-test.ts#L76

messages.content: These functions aren't exported (but I think we should make them generic and export them somehow!) but for now, you can just take them and use them in your code to do the composition and decomposition of bytes

But since Poseidon is implemented using a custom gate, it might be more efficient to hash the bytes directly rather than turning them into some other structure, which requires some additional checks (as you can see in the functions)

I see, thanks a lot for the resources! Wow, this is a lot of great stuff that's coming. I'm currently experimenting with the `Encoding` module. This is based off of the code that @DFST shared.  The challenge that I'm facing now is that the `Encoding.stringToFields()` doesn't return a fixed number of Field[] for SHA3-512 Base64 representation.

My goal is to store the individual parts, and make sure that I can convert back and forth between the O1JS representation of the digest and the raw digest.
What about `Bytes.fromString`?
This does what you need, no?
you need to extend `Bytes` to create a static sized Bytes array. `class Bytes32 extends Bytes(32) {}`
@Florian So would I just do Bytes.fromString(<base 64>).toFields()?
Oh I forgot there's a `toFields` method on `Bytes`! Yes - this turns your string into an array of bytes and gives you an array of field elements

I also see this one that's exported:

```
  /**
   * The SHA3 hash function with an output length of 512 bits.
   */
  SHA3_512: {
    /**
     * Hashes the given bytes using SHA3-512.
     *
     * This is an alias for `Keccak.nistSha3(512, bytes)`.\
     * See {@link Keccak.nistSha3} for details and usage examples.
     */
    hash(bytes: Bytes) {
      return Keccak.nistSha3(512, bytes);
    },
  },
```

So I can just do:

```
hash = Hash.SHA3_512.hash(Bytes.fromString);  // Off-chain/outside of provable computation
fields: Field[]  = hash.toFields(); // off-chain/outside of provable computation

mySHA3_512_representation = new SHA3_512({field1=fields[0], field2=fields[1], ...}); // SHA3_512 extends O1JS's struct
```

Just need to check if `fields` will always have a fixed size.
never ran `npm intall` faster!! These addtions are great.
All setup, I'll report back in a bit!

Not sure what you are trying to achieve exactly with that, can you explain? 

```ts
hash = Hash.SHA3_512.hash(Bytes.fromString);  // Off-chain/outside of provable computation
fields: Field[]  = hash.toFields(); // off-chain/outside of provable computation
```

Why outside of provable code? This works within a circuit
You do need a static sized array, that's correct, but for that you extend `function Bytes(n: number)` to create one. `class Bytes32 extends Bytes(32) {}`

The situation is the following. I have a proof of Geolocation, either exact coordinates or in a proof of the coordinates being within a polygon. I would like to attach arbitrary **metadata** to that Geolocation proof. For example, it could be a tweet, an image, a video, a blog post, or something else. The approach that I settles on is:

1. Compute SHA3-512 for the media outside of provable code
2. Convert SHA3-512 into a ZK-circuit friendly representation (e.g. Struct) outside or inside of provable code. I'm thinking outside just or performance, as I don't gain any extra security with making that convertion in circuits
3. Perform Poseidon.hash() on the ZK-circuit friendly representation (e.g. Struct). This is the Poseidon.hash(SHA3_512.hash('my bytes here')). This data is then attached/commited to the geolocation proof.
If you have any other other suggestions, I'd be more than thankful!

Thank you! Trying to understand what exactly this represents. Why would I use Bytes32 and not Bytes64? SHA3-512 is 512 bits = 64 bytes. Base64 representation would be about 90 bytes if I'm not mistaken, and hex representation 128 bytes. I'm currently decoding what the `number` argument actually does, as under the hood, it appears to be  Uint8[].

@Florian 💜 💜 💜  Thank you!!

`Bytes32.provable` - Amazing! This removes the need for the abstraction that I have. Refactoring.

FYI for hashing outside of a circuit, it's faster if you use a native SHA3 implementation rather than ours, but also requires some more conversions to make everything compatible. shouldn't be an issue on a small scale but does matter if you do a lot of hashes outside of the circuit
Thanks. In my case, it's just one hash. I'll put Bytes64.provable as a private input and leave up to the caller to construct the bytes.
@devtonite You were working on hashing files as well. What we discussed here are new features in O1JS 0.15.*

> Thanks. In my case, it's just one hash. I'll put Bytes64.provable as a private input and leave up to the caller to construct the bytes.
Also, I'd rather use the tested approach used by O1JS, since it will reduce the required testing and maintenance. Late night yesterday I was going deep into how I'm slicing hex numbers to ensure that I don't lose any bits and don't break the security guarantees of SHA3.

Hello, writing with an update.

First of all, @Florian thank you very much for your assistance. As a result of your suggestions I was able to remove over 500 lines of code (including some base tests). 

I have implemented the functionality, including an abstraction for SHA3_512.

You can find it here: https://github.com/iluxonchik/zkLocus/blob/5cd7430acfab65ab965e2a2c23572d839c522ad8/contracts/src/api/sha3/SHA3.ts

Check for usages of `class SHA3_512` and `SHA_512.provable` to see how SHA3_512 is verifiably integrated into the ZK circuits.

Read the code and the comment of `ZKGeopointProver.attachMetadata(string)` to understand how it's being used: https://github.com/iluxonchik/zkLocus/blob/5cd7430acfab65ab965e2a2c23572d839c522ad8/contracts/src/api/provers/ZKGeoPointProver.ts#L129C24-L129C24

If someome has any questions, please let me know!

Also, it would be great to put it as a separate package, and I'll write a blog post covering this in detail, but I'll have to delay that for now due to having to focus on other parts of the project.
